Migrants risk their lives to move on from Italy
https://www.economist.com/europe/2018/11/03/migrants-risk-their-lives-to-move-on-from-italy
Amid the many crosses in the cemetery of the northern Italian mountain town of Bardonecchia is a freshly dug grave with an unadorned headstone. Below it is a quotation from the Koran: “We belong to God and to Him we shall return.” The grave was dug for 28-year-old Mohamed Fofana from Guinea, who died of hypothermia in May after he and a companion were turned back by police as they tried to reach France near the Col de l’Échelle pass, 1,762 metres up in the Alps.

Two new books explain the Brexit revolt
https://www.economist.com/britain/2018/11/03/two-new-books-explain-the-brexit-revolt
As far as British politics is concerned, Brexit is the defining issue of our time. Yet even intelligent people cling to feeble explanations of why it happened. Remainers present it as a revolt of the know-nothings, despite the fact that a third of graduates voted Leave. Brexiteers counter that it was a revolt of the people against the elites, despite the fact that Brexit was popular among rich retirees in the shires, and that many of the campaign’s leaders went to expensive private schools. Others implausibly cite one-off factors, such as Russian interference or Jeremy Corbyn’s Europhobia.

Within the next few months, I do not see any other EU member announcing to leave the EU. With Brexit comes many more other complications for Britain as the process of getting out is not as simple as it may seem and therefore other countries may be pushed away from the idea of leaving. Also, one of the most troubling complications of Brexit is how to make it happen while holding the UK together as there is significant division over the action as well as trouble with the eurozone, and the troubles that go with getting out if the EU will make other countries wary of risking that (Financial Times).  Concerns in Europe are however high with Merkle saying that she will step down after her term is done, with nationalism rising and with Europeâ€™s politics  reorganized around who is for Europe, and who is against it, the next couple of years will have to be closely watched for countries that desire to follow in Britain's path (NY Times). However, for now, it seems like Britain is on its own in leaving the EU.

There is also continuous friction with Hungary and Poland, their governments are also unpredictable and have quite wide support. Yet, it is unlikely for any of these leaders to conceive a referendum while the potential Brexit deal is so unclear.

As stated in the Congressional Research Service report on the EU, most members of the EU support their country's membership.  Euroskeptic parties make up only 25% of the seats in the EU parliament and have very little cohesion among themselves.  Some of these euroskeptics have some sway in their respective countries (such as Poland and Hungary), the advantages of being in the EU far outweigh the advantages of leaving.  Also there is not enough time for an exit to occur before Jan1, 2019.  For these reasons I have given such a low probability of creating a referendum for leaving.

Its interesting that GJ has very few questions on European politics in general and only this one question about the future of the EU (or have I missed some other questions?). Considering that the post 1945 global consensus was build on the the idea of there are two centres of the western world, one being North America the other being Europe, this seems odd. It is not that Europe is so stable that nothing interesting is happening. On the contrary there are risks everywhere; to the European status quo;  a reversal of the liberalisation of Eastern Europe; strains in the Euro Zone; Brexit and the UK fading into irrelevance; the EU/US partnership being dissolved. 
Are there so few GJ questions because "times are so interesting" that no one can frame a question out of the chaos? Or because no one has any idea where Europe is heading and so the possible answers are too complex to distill into a few possible outcomes? 
The current apparently chaotic situation in the UK today regarding Brexit is not covered in any GJ question, but it was certainly not impossible to GJ Forecasters to have anticipated it, as it is not impossible to forecast possible Brexit outcomes (e.g. the UK remains in the Single Market and Customs Union or not; there is a Deal between the EU and UK, or Not; The UK Government falls or Not.)

I believe there is no chance that another state will schedule a referendum to leave the EU before 2019.  The current state of Brexit is unknown, but it has been plagued with major disagreements within the United Kingdom and between the UK and the rest of the Eurozone (BBC). No state will want to take on the task of leaving the EU until the full outcomes have been established for the United Kingdom, which will not occur before 2019. Additionally, Europe has significantâ€‹ other challenges, including economic stagnation, the migrant crisis, and the rise of populism that many states are prioritizing instead of opening up the debate to leaving the EU (LSE, Politico). While there is no denying the strong Euroscepticism that is taking hold in Europe, I do not believe it will culminate in another polity leaving the EU before 2019.

There has been a rise in nationalist anti-EU parties within Europe that have made noise about leaving the EU. Political leaders in Poland, Hungary, and Italy have all speculated about leaving the EU. The EU has also been critical of recent laws in Poland and Hungary that the EU claims is detrimental to the rule of law.

I believe there exists the potential for Poland and Hungary to hold referendums to exit the EU. Poland's PiS party holds an absolute major in the nation controlling the Presidency and parliament. The nation has seen a rise in nationalist groups that espouse principles counter to the shared values of EU nations. Since the rise of the PiS party serious questions have been raised about Poland's commitment to the rule of law, a core tenant of EU membership. Judicial reforms have purged judges from the nations courts who are being replaced by judges who are favorable to PiS party leaders. The EU has since invoked Article 7, a so-called nuclear option, to remove the voting rights of member states it feels are breaking established EU rules. In order to be enacted, this requires a unanimous vote by all EU member states. Hungary, another nation who is experiencing a rise in nationalism, has vowed to block any such measure.

Due to the recent news about the EU's interaction with Victor Orban of Hungary, and the recent elections within Italy, there may be a push to have a referendum.  There is a good possibility that both radical political parties and their respective leaders within these countries will push to have a referendum.  Although it may be damaging to the economic prospects of each country to plan a referendum to leave the EU, their histories, especially Italy, of interaction within the EU has not always been positive.  Italy suffered considerably from the austerity policies of the EU after the sovereign debt crisis of 2010.  Radical ideology could very well fuel short sighted political maneuvers over the long term policy of EU membership.  There is also considerable foreign influence within each country from Russia, which have tended to tip the scales in favor of the radical parties.  If the EU is going to prevent further idiotic "Brexits"  it is going to have to drastically change the narrative of the neoliberal political and economic norms that have been hijacked by wealthy elites, and craft policies that reconsider the popular concerns of the states within the union and its citizens.
Time is quite short to manage the logistics of scheduling.  It doesn't appear that any member state is that close to this outcome (barring the UK of course).

As the UK continues to negotiate Brexit, it will be unlikely that other member states will seek to cede until the outcome of Brexit becomes more certain. Determining the cost of the UK leaving the EU may serve as a harsh deterrent for others to follow suit and it seems improbable that Brexit negotiations will culminate before the end of the year.

Overall, EU support appears to be up, with Brexit having improved the pro-EU mood (https://www.politico.eu/article/europeans-love-the-eu-and-populists-too/). Significant changes in the government probably would be a necessary pre-condition for prompting such a referendum. Right-wing populist movements in Italy, Hungary, and Poland (among others) could provide that type of momentum (https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/05/21/in-europe-the-only-choice-is-right-or-far-right/). More recently, strong Italian Eurosceptic rhetoric this week (https://www.dw.com/en/italys-matteo-salvini-eu-has-ruined-our-country/a-45767182), but there are significant constitutional impediments to Italy actually leaving the EU, as another forecaster pointed out (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/667134). There is also the issue of timing that another forecaster raised considering the significant delay in the UK before the actual referendum was scheduled (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/665603). 1 Jan seems unlikely considering that practical matter.

Sweden may also leave the Euro but for reasons of migration. Finland's nationalist party is also gaining support and Denmark's Danish People's Party is as well.  Hungry may leave as well because of anti-immigrant reasons.

There is a possibility of another EU member state scheduling a referendum on leaving the EU or eurozone, especially Italy, Sweden or Poland, but it is unlikely to happen before 1 January 2019.  It is entirely possible that Italy will have a referendum, but it would take a lot of time and would require at least some cooperation between two parties, the Five Star Movement and the League, but they have not been cooperating as of late (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/27/opinion/italy-leave-european-union.html). In terms of Sweden, the Sweden Democrats did not win as many seats as feared in the election this year, and they are the ones who would support a referendum on leaving the EU (https://finance.yahoo.com/news/sweden-starting-talk-leaving-eu-142558459.html). So, Sweden is not likely to schedule a referendum in the near future. Poland has seen the results of a shocking poll earlier this year in which over 1/3 of citizens were in support of leaving the EU, but the current government has calmed its rhetoric somewhat and is unlikely to schedule a referendum on leaving the EU and this amount of support would still not be enough to leave the EU (https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/935620/Poland-EU-exit-Polexit-will-Poland-leave-European-Union). These are the three most likely countries to pull out of the EU or eurozone, and even they are unlikely to schedule a referendum to leave before 1 January 2019.

The UK internally has struggled greatly because of Brexit. The economy is not as strong as it has always been and resignations/instability within the government have been prominent.

Brussels has succeeded in showing the rest of its members that leaving like the UK did will result in severe punishment; which (so far) has been a very successful demotivation strategy. Also, the Eastern and Southern members have no reason to leave, as they take in much more money from Brussels than what they put in (so called moocher members). The net payers also have no reason to leave (Germany, Netherlands, Finland, Denmark) because they currently have thriving economies that they do not want to risk by suffering Brussels wrath when leaving. The unknown in the deck is France, but Macron likes his position in the spotlights on the world stage that the EU membership gives him right now, so he also has no desire to leave. The only thing that could jeopardize the EU house of cards is a drastic increase in ME and African refugees and/or a drastic increase in interest rates (the latter which could make southern member debts unmanageable and as such,  jeopardize the euro) but all that is unlikely to happen before 2019.

Like many people I have a great interest in why people voted for Brexit in 2016, so I tried to use contacts to asks Leave voters what their main motivation were in voting that way. 
The answers I got frequently seemed to be nonsensical. For example one person gave her reasons as "because the old people fought in the war" and "because of the cheaper blueberries". I had not heard anyone campaigning with any message that the EU was linked to any issue about the war (which war? WW2?) or the blueberries. So I dismissed the woman's reasons. But now I have seen the samples of  ads that were run on Facebook by Vote Leave I can see how her reasons might make sense (to her).
I had, arrogantly thought that seeing a few more adverts saying Vote for Brexit using the same arguments that I had seen were unlikely to have made much difference to the vote. But these targeted Facebook adverts are nothing like the mainstream adverts. They have pictures of cups of tea, polar bears, bull fight etc. with the suggestion that the EU is tying to stop Brits drinking tea and is blocking the UK from helping to save polar bears and encouraging bull fights. It seems there were 1433 different targeted adverts. Obviously I have not seen them all, but it seems very possible that some of them could have shown an old person or a picture of the Battle of Britain and suggesting that remaining in the EU was letting the fighters down, it seems quite possible that another of the 1433 was promoting the idea that somehow blueberries would be cheaper after Brexit. 
The fact that the Leave voter quoted the reasons she did, strongly suggests she had seen an advert telling her to vote that way. The reasons that were passed on to me as to why other Leave voters voted how they did also often seemed odd, but I had assumed the voters were just misunderstanding the arguments, not being fed pure fantasy. I know that at least some (older) voters who were getting all their news via social media  So I have changed my mind and now think these adverts could very well have changed the outcome of the vote.   
As it seems that the source of money that paid for the adverts is questionable it does look as if the result is compromised (Ignoring the over spending) an investigation similar to the USA Mueller Investigation is needed.

I believe that there is a low chance that any EU country would issue a referendum on EU membership before January 1, 2019. Many like to follow the example of Brexit, however, it should be noted that the United Kingdom was in a unique position within the European Union. The UK was granted many opt outs in areas such as the Eurozone, Schengen, and the charter of fundamental rights. Therefore, the UK was not well integrated within the EU paradigm which made its exit relatively easy, and was boosted by its large economy. Nearly all other Euroskeptic countries are part of both the Eurozone and Schengen, and their exit would create massive disruptions for their societies. The Pew Research Center has also conducted a major study and has found that nearly a year after the Brexit vote, the view of the EU has become more positive and there is not widespread appetite for leaving the Union. However, Pew research notes that there is a slight increase in citizens who want a referendum on membership. However, it is still not a considerable majority and the governments face no pressure to implement a referendum, especially more Euroskeptic countries in the V4, who still rely on EU funds for their economy. However, there is still a concern over Greece, as the Greek economy has still not properly recovered from the Eurozone crisis. The Euro is also a culprit in holding back Greece, as they cannot rely on their own national currency, the drachma, to drop in value and make their exports more competitive and help alleviate some of the economic issues. The Greek people also despise the austerity measures imposed upon them by the IMF and the EU, and have elected a new government in 2015 in the hopes of ending the measures, but to little avail. If the issue is not resolved soon, there could be a desperate push for a referendum, but there is still a debate of whether the benefits outweigh the costs.

Of the countries still in the Eurozone the most divisive issues have not been unfair wealth distribution issues which triggered Brexit, but personal ownership of firearms where countries who came out of communism are much more likely to resist a Eurozone wide gun control scheme, however I do not anticipate that this issue will rise to the level of a "Czechout" or other such action as each sovereign nation maintains other legal mechanisms to protect gun rights of their citizens (such as declare all citizens members of the militia who are authorized to outfit themselves with necessary arms and provisions).

I think that overall it is unlikely that an EU member state will schedule a referendum on leaving the EU or eurozone before 1 January 2019 because that is a relatively short time frame. However, the continued rise of populism in Europe and some recent developments in Brexit negotiations render it possible. The world has seen many European populist movements arise and gain popularity in Europe over the past few years. Most recently in early March Italian elections, a majority of votes went to the Five Star Movement, which is willing to work alongside other far right parties against the euro and immigration in Italy. Further, in Brexit negotiations a new agreement has been reached regarding the transition period in which the UK will officially leave the EU and the two parties will begin negotiating trade and future relations. As long as populist movements continue to rise in European countries and the UK provides a successful model for leaving the EU, it is possible that another country will schedule a referendum to leave. However given the short time frame I feel that it is very unlikely in the near future, although in the long-term I believe it is highly likely other countries will attempt to leave the EU.

2 Referendums held on EU membership (if you count Greenland as a state). Calculating rate of referendums by multiplying the number of country-days in EU, dividing by number of referendums, gives a probabilty of an individual country holding a referendum on any day. Given that referendums need to be scheduled, and I am not aware of an EU membership referendum being scheduled and not taking place, I substitute probability of referendum being held with probability of referendum being scheduled (though in reality scheduling a referendum would be slightly more likely). Taking all the individual country base rate probabilities into account, I get a base rate (as of today) of 5.3%. I consider it unlikely that a government would schedule a referendum without promising it in a general election, therefore I halve the base rate for countries without elections in 2018. The EU has every incentive to punish the UK for leaving to prevent other member states from leaving as well. However, several elections this year in eastern Europe could lead to another exit. The Czech Republic recently had elections with the incumbent reelected who is pro-Russian and an EU critic. Elections in Poland and Hungary could lead to far right nationalist parties gaining power or more center-right parties appealing to them. Viktor Orban may support leaving the EU to show strength on border security and immigration. But overall, I think most leaders and parties will calculate that the costs of leaving this year are worth the political boost.

Because being in favor of EU membership is one of the salient features of incumbent parties generally, opposing it is a common feature in existing opposition parties. While populist parties have made significant gains in many countries such as Poland, Hungary, Greece and others, even in countries where they hold majorities they have to weigh significant economic drawbacks to leaving the EU. While the zeal to limit immigration might result in a referendum, Britain provides these countries with a powerful recent example of the complications and drawbacks. A similar though imperfect situation might be the behavior of secessionist states prior to the American Civil War, where the contentious issue of slavery was also tied to powerful economic incentives for southern states to secede. EU countries do not have the economic incentive, thus making it much less likely.

Given the complexity and difficulty of the Brexit negotiations, I think other EU member states won't be quick to hold a referendum and risk putting themselves in a similar position. The Pew Research Center did a study that found a sharp increase in EU favorability in many member states in the last year. Although xenophobia and some nationalist rhetoric has been on the rise, the majority of Europe, including key leaders Macron and Merkel, believe strongly in the EU and its institutions. Europe has its own identity that coexists simultaneously with individual national identities. So my conclusion is that as far as calling for anti-EU referendums is concerned, for populists, its better to get your supports to believe voting for you is a way of traveling hopefully toward Leaving, but be very sure there is no danger of arriving.  Scheduling a referendum would therefore be a very big mistake.

There are two questions here - one on whether other EU states will have a referendum to leave the Eurozone ie the euro currency that is used by most members of the European Union and the second on whether other EU states will hold a referendum similar to that held in the UK in 2016.  These are two separate but related issues.
With regards to the Eurozone, there is different opinion on whether or not leaving the euro currency is legal and (since the crash of 2007/8) the eurozone itself has established a number of new provisions and the funding for emergency loans which makes the likelihood of a country wishing to leave the euro for economic purposes highly unlikely.  Indeed, any replacement currency would be of low value compared to the euro and is likely to lead to a bank run, divestment and the introduction of capital controls.  It is highly unlikely that a mainstream political party would risk the potential economic risks of holding such a referendum.
For countries that are both members of the EU and the eurozone, it would be unlikely that a referendum would be called that proposed leaving the EU but maintaining membership of the eurozone (this is potentially possible as some non-EU countries use the euro as their main currency) as the call for a referendum would be primarily based on nationalist terms and therefore an outright rejection of the European ideal.  Furthermore, countries that do have nationalist and eurosceptic governments (eg Austria) are more likely to wait to see what terms UK will be given ahead of its planned departure in March 2019.  The complexity of leaving the EU, such as transcribing EU law in UK law, setting up new trade deals etc. has demonstrated that leaving the EU should not be taken lightly and, in fact, there are now calls in the UK to have another referendum to ratify the previous one that decided to leave the EU by such a small margin.
Overall, therefore, it is very highly unlikely that another EU member state will hold a referendum before March 2019.

Currently there is one country were a concrete EU-referendum seems at least possible: The Czech Republic. The governing ANO-Party is eurosceptic but not in favor of a referendum as a potential withdrawal from the Union could have negative ramifications for the Czech economy. Nervetheless there are presidential elections in january with all of the main contenders being not against  EU-membership (except of the SPD-candidate) but in favor of a referendum.
Still a president is in need of parliamentarian approval for a referendum bill. The anti-EU forces possess (mainly ODS, SPD and KSCM) 62 of 200 seats (101 needed for a majority), excluding ANO as their leader is no advocate of a referendum. There could be some ANO-delegates who vote in favour of a referendum. 
Thus the chances for a pro-referendum president are indeed relatively high (about 60%) and about 31% of the delegates are probably in favour of a referendum.
